segment.source: Configure security policy settings (Windows 10)
segment.target: Configure security policy settings (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes steps to configure a security policy setting on the local device, on a domain-joined device, and on a domain controller.
segment.target: Describes steps to configure a security policy setting on the local device, on a domain-joined device, and on a domain controller.

segment.source: Configure security policy settings
segment.target: Configure security policy settings

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes steps to configure a security policy setting on the local device, on a domain-joined device, and on a domain controller.
segment.target: Describes steps to configure a security policy setting on the local device, on a domain-joined device, and on a domain controller.

segment.source: You must have Administrators rights on the local device, or you must have the appropriate permissions to update a Group Policy Object (GPO) on the domain controller to perform these procedures.
segment.target: You must have Administrators rights on the local device, or you must have the appropriate permissions to update a Group Policy Object (GPO) on the domain controller to perform these procedures.

segment.source: When a local setting is inaccessible, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is inaccessible, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: To configure a setting using the Local Security Policy console
segment.target: To configure a setting using the Local Security Policy console

segment.source: To open Local Security Policy, on the Start screen, type secpol.msc, and then press ENTER.
segment.target: To open Local Security Policy, on the Start screen, type secpol.msc, and then press ENTER.

segment.source: Under Security Settings of the console tree, do one of the following:
segment.target: Under Security Settings of the console tree, do one of the following:

segment.source: Click Account Policies to edit the Password Policy or Account Lockout Policy.
segment.target: Click Account Policies to edit the Password Policy or Account Lockout Policy.

segment.source: Click Local Policies to edit an Audit Policy, a User Rights Assignment, or Security Options.
segment.target: Click Local Policies to edit an Audit Policy, a User Rights Assignment, or Security Options.

segment.source: When you find the policy setting in the details pane, double-click the security policy that you want to modify.
segment.target: When you find the policy setting in the details pane, double-click the security policy that you want to modify.

segment.source: Modify the security policy setting, and then click OK.
segment.target: Modify the security policy setting, and then click OK.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Some security policy settings require that the device be restarted before the setting takes effect.
segment.target: Some security policy settings require that the device be restarted before the setting takes effect.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: To configure a security policy setting using the Local Group Policy Editor console
segment.target: To configure a security policy setting using the Local Group Policy Editor console

segment.source: You must have the appropriate permissions to install and use the Microsoft Management Console (MMC), and to update a Group Policy Object (GPO) on the domain controller to perform these procedures.
segment.target: You must have the appropriate permissions to install and use the Microsoft Management Console (MMC), and to update a Group Policy Object (GPO) on the domain controller to perform these procedures.

segment.source: Open the Local Group Policy Editor (gpedit.msc).
segment.target: Open the Local Group Policy Editor (gpedit.msc).

segment.source: In the console tree, click Computer Configuration, click Windows Settings, and then click Security Settings.
segment.target: In the console tree, click Computer Configuration, click Windows Settings, and then click Security Settings.

segment.source: Do one of the following:
segment.target: Do one of the following:

segment.source: Click Account Policies to edit the Password Policy or Account Lockout Policy.
segment.target: Click Account Policies to edit the Password Policy or Account Lockout Policy.

segment.source: Click Local Policies to edit an Audit Policy, a User Rights Assignment, or Security Options.
segment.target: Click Local Policies to edit an Audit Policy, a User Rights Assignment, or Security Options.

segment.source: In the details pane, double-click the security policy setting that you want to modify.
segment.target: In the details pane, double-click the security policy setting that you want to modify.

segment.source: Note: If this security policy has not yet been defined, select the Define these policy settings check box.
segment.target: Note: If this security policy has not yet been defined, select the Define these policy settings check box.

segment.source: Modify the security policy setting, and then click OK.
segment.target: Modify the security policy setting, and then click OK.

segment.source: Note: If you want to configure security settings for many devices on your network, you can use the Group Policy Management Console.
segment.target: Note: If you want to configure security settings for many devices on your network, you can use the Group Policy Management Console.

segment.source: To configure a setting for a domain controller
segment.target: To configure a setting for a domain controller

segment.source: The following procedure describes how to configure a security policy setting for only a domain controller (from the domain controller).
segment.target: The following procedure describes how to configure a security policy setting for only a domain controller (from the domain controller).

segment.source: To open the domain controller security policy, in the console tree, locate GroupPolicyObject ComputerName Policy, click Computer Configuration, click Windows Settings, and then click Security Settings.
segment.target: To open the domain controller security policy, in the console tree, locate GroupPolicyObject ComputerName Policy, click Computer Configuration, click Windows Settings, and then click Security Settings.

segment.source: Do one of the following:
segment.target: Do one of the following:

segment.source: Double-click Account Policies to edit the Password Policy, Account Lockout Policy, or Kerberos Policy.
segment.target: Double-click Account Policies to edit the Password Policy, Account Lockout Policy, or Kerberos Policy.

segment.source: Click Local Policies to edit the Audit Policy, a User Rights Assignment, or Security Options.
segment.target: Click Local Policies to edit the Audit Policy, a User Rights Assignment, or Security Options.

segment.source: In the details pane, double-click the security policy that you want to modify.
segment.target: In the details pane, double-click the security policy that you want to modify.

segment.source: Note If this security policy has not yet been defined, select the Define these policy settings check box.
segment.target: Note If this security policy has not yet been defined, select the Define these policy settings check box.

segment.source: Modify the security policy setting, and then click OK.
segment.target: Modify the security policy setting, and then click OK.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Always test a newly created policy in a test organizational unit before you apply it to your network.
segment.target: Always test a newly created policy in a test organizational unit before you apply it to your network.

segment.source: When you change a security setting through a GPO and click OK, that setting will take effect the next time you refresh the settings.
segment.target: When you change a security setting through a GPO and click OK, that setting will take effect the next time you refresh the settings.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Security policy settings reference
segment.target: Security policy settings reference
